edu.udel.cis.vsl.sarl.simplify.common

Class IntervalUnionSet

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.udel.cis.vsl.sarl.simplify.common.IntervalUnionSet
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Range

    public class IntervalUnionSet
extends java.lang.Object
implements Range

    Implementation of Range in which a set is represented as a finite union of intervals. This class is immutable.

    The following are invariants. They force there to be a unique representation for each set of numbers:

    1. All intervals in the array are non-null Intervals.
    2. An empty interval cannot occur in the array.
    3. All of the intervals in the array are disjoint.
    4. The intervals in the array are ordered from least to greatest.
    5. If an interval has the form {a,+infty}, then it is open on the right. If an interval has the form {-infty,a}, then it is open on the left.
    6. If {a,b} and {b,c} are two consecutive intervals in the list, the first one must be open on the right and the second one must be open on the left.
    7. If the range set has integer type, all of the intervals are integer intervals. If it has real type, all of the intervals are real intervals. (All integral intervals are actually )
    8. If the range set has integer type, all of the intervals are closed, except for +infty and -infty.

      Constructs an IntervalUnionSet with two Numbers , two boolean representing whether the bound is closed or not, and one boolean showing whether the IntervalUnionSet is a integral one or not.

      • affineTransform

        public Range affineTransform(Number a,
                    Number b)
        Description copied from interface: Range
        Computes the set aX+b, where X is this set. That is, the set of all numbers of the form ax+b, where x is in this set. (For integral Interval set, it will return the set including all transformed integers, which are contained in the original set.)
        Specified by:
        affineTransform in interface Range
        Parameters:
        a - a number of the same type as this set
        b - a number of the same type as this set
        Returns:
        the set aX+b, where X is the set of numbers in this set

      • complement

        public Range complement()
        Description copied from interface: Range
        Computes the complement of this set. If this has integer type, that is the set of all integers not in this set. If this has real type, it is the set of all reals not in this set.
        Specified by:
        complement in interface Range
        Returns:
        the complement of this set

      • symbolicRepresentation

        public BooleanExpression symbolicRepresentation(SymbolicConstant x,
                                       PreUniverse universe)
        Description copied from interface: Range
        Given a symbolic constant x, returns a boolean expression which holds iff x is in this range.

        Example: suppose this range is the interval (0,1]. Given x, this method will return the boolean symbolic expression x>0 && x<=1.

        Example: (0,1] U [4,5]. Given x, returns (x>0 && x<=1) || (x>=4 && x<=5).

        Specified by:
        symbolicRepresentation in interface Range
        Parameters:
        x - variable to use in the new expression
        universe - symbolic universe used to construct the symbolic expression
        Returns:
        a boolean expression involving x which holds iff x is in this set

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • checkInvariants

        public boolean checkInvariants()
        To check all invariants of this IntervalUnionSet Those invariants are: 1. All of intervals in the array are non-null intervals. 2. An empty interval cannot occur in the array. 3. All of the intervals in the array are disjoint. 4. The intervals in the array are ordered from least to greatest. 5. If an interval has the form {a,+infty}, then it is open on the right. If an interval has the form {-infty,a}, then it is open on the left. 6. If {a,b} and {b,c} are two consecutive intervals in the list, the the first one must be open on the right and the second one must be open on the left. 7. If the range set has integer type, all of the intervals are integer intervals. If it has real type, all of the intervals are real intervals. 8. If the range set has integer type, all of the intervals are closed, except for +infty and -infty.
        Returns:
        true iff every Interval in this set ensures invariants (Because all IntervalUnionSet constructors would ensure those invariants, this function should always return the value of true)
